div.l: That ilke frute is eủere lenger the wers
Tyl it be roten in mullok or in stree
We olde men I drede so fare we
Tyl we be roten can we nat be rype
We hoppen̄ alwey whil that the world wole pype
For in our͗e wyl there styketh eủere a nayle
To haue an hore here and a grene taile
As hath a leke for though our͗e myght be gone
Oure wil desireth foly eủere in one
For whan we may done than wole we speke
Yet in oure asshen olde is fier y reke
iiij gledes haue we whiche I shall deuyse
Auauntyng lyeng anger and couetyse
These iiij sparkes longen̄ vn to elde
Oure olde lymes may weel ben̄ onwelde
But wil ne shal nat faylen that is sothe
And yet haue I alwey a coltes tothe
Als many a yeer as it passed henne
Syth þat my tap of lyfe by gan to renne
For sykerly whan I was borne a none
Deth drough the tappe of lyf and lete it gone
And eủer sythe hath so the tappe y ronne
Till þat all moost as empty is þe tonne
The streme of lyfe now droppeth on the chymbe
The sely tonge may weel rynge and clymbe
Of wretchednesse þat passed is full yore
With olde folk saf dotage is no more
Whan that our͗e oste hadde herde this ʆsermonyng
He gan to speke als lordely as a kyng
He seide what amounteth all þe witte
What shall we speke all day of holy writte
The deuel made a Reve for to preche
Or of a Souter Shipman̄ or a leche
Sey forth thy tale and tary nat þi tyme
Lo Depforth and it is half weye pryme
Lo Grenewiche þat many a shrewe is ynne
It were all tyme thy tale for to gynne
Now seres qᵈuod this Oswalde the Reve
I pray yow alle that ye take it to no greve
Thow I answer͗e and somdel sette his hoghe
For lefull is with force · force to showe
This dronken̄ myller hath y tolde vs here
How þat beguyled was a Carpent̉ere
For ꝑparauentᵘure by cause I am one
And by your͗e leve I shall hym quyte a none
Right in hise cherles t̉ermes wole I speke
I pᵃray to god hise nekke mote to to y breke
He can weel in myne eye seen̄ a stalke
But in hise owen̄ he can seen a balke
At Trūmpyngton̄ nat fer fro Cant̉erbrigge CambriggeMarginalium in later hand
Ther͗e goth a broke and oủere þat a brigge
Vpon whiche broke th̉ere stante a mylle
This is a v̉erray sothe that I yow telle
A Miller was there duellyng many a day
As eny pecok he was proude and gay
Pipen̄ he coude and fysshen̄ and nettes bete
And torne cuppes and weel wrastlee and shete
Ay by his bolte he bare a long panade
And of a swerde full trenchaıı̄unt was the blade
A ioly popper bare he in hise pouche
Ther͗e was no man for perel durst hym touche
A sheffeld thwytel bare in hise hose
Rounde was hise face and camuse was his nose
As pylled as an ape was his sculle
He was a market beter at the fulle
Ther͗e was no wight þat on hym hande durst legge
But if he swore he shuld a none a begge
A thief he was forsothe of corne and mele
And þat a sligh and vsant for to stele
His name was hoten̄ deynous Symkyn̄
A wyfe he had comen̄ of a noble kynne
The ꝑperson̄ of þe toun̄ hir fadre was
With hir he gaf ful many a panne a bras
For þat Symken̄ shuld in his blood allye
She was y fostred in a nonnerye
For Symken wolde no wyfe as he seide
But if she were weel y norysshed and a mayde
To sauen̄ hise estate of yomanrye
And she was proude and perte as a pye
A full faire sight was it vpon hem twoo
On haly dayes byforne hir wolde he goo
With hise typet wounden a bout his hed
And she cam after in a guyte of reed
And Symkyn̄ hadde hosen̄ of the same
Ther͗e durst no wight clepen hire but dame
Was non so hardy that wente by the waye
That with hire durst ones rage or playe
